questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your company plans to upgrade to Microsoft Teams from Microsoft Skype for Business Online. The org-wide coexistence mode for Microsoft Teams is set to
Teams Only.
The company has a user named User1.
You need to implement a migration solution that meets the following requirements:
✑ User1 must be able to chat and create meetings by using Skype for Business only.
✑ User1 must be able to read and post messages by using Microsoft Teams channels.
How should you complete the PowerShell command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: On exam 04-Mar-2022

This is correct. At first it didn't seem right, but SfBWithTeamsCollab will allow user to post messages in team channels, but private chat is disabled. As per the question, Users needs to post messages in team channels
On Exam 28.02.22
SfBWithTeamsCollab is correct as the user need to use team for collaboration to read and post a message and rest is done by SfB

comments.content:
✑ User1 must be able to chat and create meetings by using Skype for Business only.

"Only". In Islands the user "evaluate both clients side by side"

discussion.content:
✑ User1 must be able to chat and create meetings by using Skype for Business only.
✑ User1 must be able to read and post messages by using Microsoft Teams channels. (***must be able to chat still using Teams as well as SfB)

Options:
Islands - Default configuration. Allows a single user to evaluate both clients side by side. Chats and calls can land in either client, so users must always run both clients.

SfBOnly - Calling, chat functionality and meeting scheduling in the Teams app are disabled.

SfBWithTeamsCollab - Calling, chat functionality and meeting scheduling in the Teams app are disabled.

SfBWithTeamsCollabAndMeetings - Calling and chat functionality in the Teams app are disabled.

UpgradeToTeams - Use this mode to upgrade users to Teams and to prevent chat, calling, and meeting scheduling in Skype for Business.

I think the answer is actually "Islands"
Correct
Guest settings like these can be controlled via Azure AD -> Users -> User Settings - > External Users - > Manage external collaboration settings

comments.content:
After 2 years and 8 months. This is still valid.
Azure AD> External Identities> External Collaboration Settings. Guest user access and Guest Invite Settings.

discussion.content:
Global meeting policy is for meeting settings, not for setting who can collaborate in teams and whether they are allowed to invite others. The goal is not met, B is correct.

correct answer is B

If any one wants contribution access questions please text me on +91 8143123863
the correct anwser is B because you can anly do it in Azure AD not mirosoft teams admin center
B - No. https://snipboard.io/fBFy5Q.jpg
Global Meeting Policy only addresses part of the problem and does not provide the entire Solution. Answer is B

Only guest users from specific domains must be allowed to connect to collaborate by using Microsoft Teams - this action can be performed in Teams admin centre > org wide settings> external access > add domain
The second action is performed in Azure AD > users > user settings > external users >mange external collab settings > guest invite settings > Guest can invite > no
So the answer is B - No
From Teams admin you can't control Guest Domains , but only in Azure AD

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You plan to configure the environment to allow external users to collaborate in Microsoft Teams by using guest access.
The company implements a new security policy that has the following requirements:
✑ Only guest users from specific domains must be allowed to connect to collaborate by using Microsoft Teams.
✑ Guest users must be prevented from inviting other guests.
You need to recommend a solution to meet the security policy requirements.
Solution: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, you modify the global meeting policy.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
The Network Testing Companion includes the following two tests as part of the network readiness assessment for Microsoft Teams:

 Video quality tests (B): These tests evaluate the performance and quality of video calls within Microsoft Teams. They assess factors such as latency, jitter, and packet loss to ensure optimal video communication.

 Audio quality tests (D): Similar to video quality tests, audio quality tests focus on evaluating the performance and clarity of audio calls in Teams. They help identify any issues related to call quality, such as echo, distortion, or dropped audio.

Selected Answer: CD
Answer: C/D
https://www.lync.se/2019/09/network-testing-companion/

Selected Answer: CE
The two tests included in the network readiness assessment for Microsoft Teams using the Network Testing Companion are:

C. Open and blocked ports: This test checks whether the necessary ports required for Microsoft Teams are open and accessible or if they are blocked, which could hinder the proper functioning of the application.

E. Quality of Service (QoS) validation: This test assesses the Quality of Service settings on the network to ensure that Microsoft Teams can deliver a reliable and high-quality audio and vídeo experience.

Selected Answer: CD
Right, Connectivity firstly and then the Audio Quality Test

A. trace route information
B. video quality tests

The Network Testing Companion for Microsoft Teams includes two tests that are used to assess network readiness for deploying Teams:

A. trace route information: This test provides information on the route that network traffic takes between the user's device and the Teams service. This information can be used to identify network bottlenecks and other issues that could affect performance.

B. video quality tests: This test measures the quality of the video feed that is received by the user's device. This includes factors such as frame rate, resolution, and packet loss.

It's important to note that options C, D and E are not included in the assessment, Open and blocked ports are related to network security, audio quality tests are related to the audio quality in calls, and Quality of Service (QoS) validation is related to network traffic prioritization.
... ChatGPT said

Selected Answer: CD
correct answer is CD
Answer is correct...just used the tool...video is not supported
why video quality tests is not needed?

comments.content: No, you need to install the Network Assessment Tool to use the Network Testing Companion. By the way, this dependency is something another question asks about.

discussion.content: Wasn't this tool replaced with network assessment tool?

questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy Microsoft Teams to a remote location.
You perform a network readiness assessment for Microsoft Teams by using the Network Testing Companion.
Which two tests are included in the assessment? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Answer is definitely D, also documented here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/qos-in-teams#validate-your-qos-implementation
CQD is mentioned there only for helping too decide if the port rannge needs to be adjusted.

Repeat of question 34:
https://www.examtopics.com/exams/microsoft/ms-700/view/23/

I think the keywords in the question are "specific times of the day"
AI answer is.

To verify whether Quality of Service (QoS) is being applied to the calls, you should use B. Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard. This tool provides rich set of reports, including call quality at different times of the day, and can help you troubleshoot call quality issues in Microsoft Teams. It also allows you to check if QoS policies are being applied correctly. The other options are not specifically designed for this purpose. The Microsoft Teams client (A) is the application used for making the calls, Network Testing Companion © is used for testing network performance, and Network Monitor (D) is a protocol analyzer. None of these provide the specific QoS information that the Call Quality Dashboard does.

Selected Answer: C
To verify whether Quality of Service (QoS) is being applied to the voice calls made from Microsoft Teams, you should use option C, Network Testing Companion. This tool allows you to assess the network conditions and test the connection quality specifically for Microsoft Teams. By using Network Testing Companion, you can analyze the network performance, including metrics like latency, jitter, and packet loss, which can affect call quality. It will help you determine if QoS is being applied correctly and identify any network issues that may be causing poor call quality at specific times of the day.

Selected Answer: B
B. Microsoft's Call Quality Dashboard.

The Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) is a tool that provides detailed information about the quality of voice and video calls in Microsoft Teams. It allows administrators to analyze bandwidth, packet loss, delay, and other metrics to identify call quality issues and take steps to resolve them.

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard.

To verify whether Quality of Service (QoS) is being applied to the calls, you can use the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard. This dashboard provides insights into the call quality of Microsoft Teams and Skype for Business calls, including information on call reliability, network performance, and call quality issues.

Selected Answer: D
You can not see DCSP mark on CDQ. This can only be done with a network monitoring tool at both ends of the call. You may have configured QoS within Teams but if there is a packet shaper at either end, the DCSP marker may be removed and CDQ will not show this.

The answer is D. 

Guaranteed.

Selected Answer: B
It's B. D is outdated

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/monitor-call-quality-qos

Answer is B . https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/monitor-call-quality-qos

Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) gives you a network-wide view of call quality across your organization. Use CQD information to help you identify and fix problems. First, Set up CQD. Then read Manage call and meeting quality in Teams.

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/plan-configure-network-settings-for-microsoft-teams/05-implement-quality-service

Validate the QoS implementation
For the QoS to be effective, the DSCP value set by the Group Policy object needs to be present at both ends of a call. By analyzing the traffic generated by the Teams client, you can verify if the DSCP value has not changed or been stripped out when the Teams workload traffic traverses moves through the network. It is also recommended that you use the Call Analytics and Call Quality Dashboard for evaluating your changes.

Network Monitor is the archived protocol analyzer and is no longer under development
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/troubleshoot-tcpip-netmon

comments.content:
Read again carefully: the Call quality dashboard is an additional tool, but not the main method of checking. What is described requires a network monitor tool.
The link you provide to the article informing Network Monitor has been deprecated specifically suggest "using another, non-Microsoft network protocol analyzer tool".

discussion.content: Question should say "a network monitor" in my opinion. Network Monitor sounds like an embedded tool such as CQD etc

Selected Answer: D
Correct answer is D - Network monitor
Justification - I have used this tool extensively to verify DSCP values against the posrt range for audio, video and application sharing set in QoS. The network monitor tool needs to be run at client and server level (in case of on-prem but not possible in Teams :P ) Hope this is a clear answer

Selected Answer: D
Only a network monitor that can inspect the packet will show if the QoS marking is applied

Answer is correct
Validate the QoS implementation
For the QoS to be effective, the DSCP value set by the Group Policy object needs to be present at both ends of a call. By analyzing the traffic generated by the Teams client, you can verify if the DSCP value has not changed or been stripped out when the Teams workload traffic traverses moves through the network. It is also recommended that you use the Call Analytics and Call Quality Dashboard for evaluating your changes.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-server/networking/network-monitor-3
In addition, I logged into the CQD. It appears to heave only trends and performance counters. I don't see anywhere that indicates if QOS is being applied or not.

This one appears to be correct:
"you capture traffic at the network egress point. You can use port mirroring on a switch or router to help with this."

The only way to verify DSCP is applied at both ends, is by analyzing the traffic generated by the Teams client. When they use the term "network monitor" they mean any tool that can capture network traffic and analyze the packets. you can use Wireshark to accomplish this for example.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/qos-in-teams#validate-your-qos-implementation

https://cloudbrothers.info/en/optimize-your-microsoft-teams-traffic-with-qos-on-a-unifi-usg/
is it not A?? Link: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/qos-in-teams#validate-your-qos-implementation States "By analyzing the traffic generated by the Teams client"
Correct answer is D.
https://www.ismyconnect.com/Welcome/DownloadDocument/305/Is+My+Connect_MS_Teams.pdf Check page 9.

QoS works at a different OSI layer and thus you need to check DSCP markings, which is best done using Network Monitor (or WireShark but they won't push another product!). I don't think you'll see the DSCP markings in CQD so it can't be that option I think.
I believe that CQD only shows that there is a problem, but it does not assure that the root cause is that QoS is not being applied. I choose D.
Quality of service (Qos) = network traffic , and to monitor network traffic at specific times of the day you will need a network monitoring tool. D correct

Q = You need to verify whether QoS..................
Key word: Verify

CQD doesn't give U that

As stated in the URL above:
-> For QoS to be effective, the DSCP value set by the Group Policy object needs to be present at both ends of a call. By analyzing the traffic generated by the Teams client, you can verify that the DSCP value isn’t changed or stripped out when the Teams workload traffic moves through the network.

Preferably, you capture traffic at the network egress point. You can use port mirroring on a switch or router to help with this. <-

So it's Netmon (or WireShark) to check if the DSCP markings make it 'End2End'

.... U could also check if the DSCP markings were received for an individual call:
TAC -> Users -> User -> Call History -> Call -> Debug : Connectivity_RecvDSCP

comments.content: where are you getting this from and what does it mean? What is DSCP value. It's not clearly explained on Microsoft documents, and there is no mention of the phrase 'network monitor'.
Can't see any mention of the phrase 'network monitor'.
It is D, CQD is not mentioned for verifying QOS in the article you linked

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer - Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) to identify problems and then make adjustments using QoS and selective bandwidth additions.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/qos-in-teams#validate-the-qos-implementation
B. Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard
I think correct answer is B. The dashboard will show how many calls were established and for how many QoS was not applied.

comments.content:
I strongly disagree: you might have PL or jitter even with QoS applied (or its misconfiguration could be the very reason of those).
D is the correct answer as the tool shows if packets are DCSP marked or not at the egress of the network interface of the client.
B will also show jitter and packet loss which is an indication QoS isnt working.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
When making voice calls from Microsoft Teams, users report poor call quality at specific times of the day.
You need to verify whether Quality of Service (QoS) is being applied to the calls.
What should you use?

discussion.content:
"Using Phone System with Teams is only supported when the user is in TeamsOnly mode."

Source: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/cloud-voice-landing-page
For an organization that is upgrading to Teams, the ultimate goal is to move all users to TeamsOnly mode. Using Phone System with Teams is only supported when the user is in TeamsOnly mode.

Using Teams Phone is only supported when the user is in TeamsOnly mode.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/cloud-voice-landing-page#migrate-your-existing-voice-solution-to-teams

Selected Answer: B
Island mode: "Default configuration. Allows a single user to evaluate both clients side by side. Chats and calls can land in either client, so users must always run both clients." Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/skype/grant-csteamsupgradepolicy?view=skype-ps

I suspect a bogus question that is missing information as to where they want meetings hosted. Islands and Teams Only aren't Co-existance modes, and you can apply Phone System to accounts well in advance, and should, of migrating users to Teams Only.

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C
Correct!

choices.D: Skype for Business with Teams collaboration and meetings
choices.A: Skype for Business with Teams collaboration

questions.question_text:
Your company has 200 users.
You plan to upgrade all the users from Microsoft Skype for Business Online to Microsoft Teams. Phone System with Teams must be enabled for all users.
You need to recommend a coexistence mode for the Microsoft Teams upgrade policy.
Which mode should you recommend?
